title: 106_hr2903
content:
The Act titled "Striped Bass Conservation, Atlantic Coastal Fisheries Management, and Marine Mammal Rescue Assistance Act of 2000" authorizes appropriations for the conservation of Atlantic Striped Bass for fiscal years 2001, 2002, and 2003. It includes funding for the Secretary of Commerce and the Secretary of the Interior. Additionally, there is a provision for a population study of Striped Bass. The Secretaries, in consultation with the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission, will conduct a study to determine the distribution of year classes in the Atlantic striped bass population for sustainable fishing opportunities. They will consider long-term stock assessment data and peer-reviewed research funded under the Atlantic Striped Bass Conservation Act. A report must be submitted to the Committee on Resources of the House of Representatives within 180 days of the enactment of this Act. The Secretaries, in consultation with the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission, will conduct a study to determine the distribution of year classes in the Atlantic striped bass population for sustainable fishing opportunities. A report with a long-term plan to ensure a balanced population structure of Atlantic striped bass, including older fish, must be submitted to the Committee on Resources of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate. Authorization is given for $250,000 to be appropriated to the Secretary of Commerce for this purpose. Subtitle B--Atlantic Coastal Fisheries Cooperative Management

SEC. 121. SHORT TITLE.

This subtitle is known as the "Atlantic Coastal Fisheries Act of 2000".

SEC. 122. REAUTHORIZATION OF ATLANTIC COASTAL FISHERIES COOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT ACT.

Authorization of Appropriations under Section 811 of the Atlantic Coastal Fisheries Cooperative Management Act is amended. To carry out the Atlantic Coastal Fisheries Act of 2000, $10,000,000 is authorized annually from 2001 to 2005. The funds can support the Commission's cooperative statistics program. Technical corrections include amending certain sections and changing references from "Magnuson Fishery" to "Magnuson-Stevens Fishery". Reports are required as part of the Act. The Secretary requires annual and biennial reports on the use of financial assistance provided under the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Act. Annual reports are to be submitted by the Commission and each State receiving assistance, while biennial reports are to be submitted to Congress evaluating the success of the assistance in implementing the Act. The "Marine Mammal Rescue Assistance Act of 2000" establishes the John H. Prescott Marine Mammal Rescue Assistance Grant Program under the Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972. The John H. Prescott Marine Mammal Rescue Assistance Grant Program provides grants to eligible stranding network participants for the recovery or treatment of marine mammals, data collection for scientific research, and facility operation costs directly related to these purposes. Funds are distributed equitably among designated stranding regions, with preference given to facilities with established records for rescuing or rehabilitating marine mammals. The John H. Prescott Marine Mammal Rescue Assistance Grant Program prioritizes regions based on stranding events, average annual strandings, and marine mammal population size. To receive a grant, participants must submit an application, and the Secretary consults with the Marine Mammal Commission and designated representatives. The John H. Prescott Marine Mammal Rescue Assistance Grant Program involves representatives from designated stranding regions and organizations involved in marine mammal rescue, rehabilitation, research, and conservation. Grants are limited to $100,000 with a 25% matching requirement for non-Federal costs. The section outlines the amount of funds and fair market value of property and services provided by non-Federal sources for the activity. The Secretary can use up to 6% or $80,000 for administrative expenses. Definitions include 'designated stranding region' and 'Secretary'. Authorization of appropriations is set at $5,000,000 for each fiscal year 2001 through 2003. The Marine Mammal Protection Act authorizes funds for the years 2001 through 2003, with $4,000,000 available to the Secretary of Commerce and $1,000,000 available to the Secretary of the Interior. A conforming amendment is made to Section 3(12)(B) of the Act, and clerical amendments are made to the table of contents. SEC. 203. STUDY OF THE EASTERN GRAY WHALE POPULATION. The Secretary of Commerce will conduct a study on the environmental factors affecting the eastern gray whale population's mortality increase. Information from studies on the western gray whale population will also be considered to better understand both populations' dynamics. Authorization of appropriations is included. Authorization of Appropriations: $290,000 for fiscal year 2001 and $500,000 for each fiscal year from 2002 to 2004 are authorized for the Secretary to carry out this section. The Secretary of Commerce may convey a retired fishery research vessel to American Samoa without cost, for their use. The vessel must be in operable condition and cannot be conveyed until a replacement vessel is in active service. The US government will not be responsible for maintenance or operation of the conveyed vessel after delivery to American Samoa. SEC. 205. Technical and conforming amendments related to national marine sanctuary designation standards. Technical Amendment to the National Marine Sanctuaries Act involves criteria for designating areas of special national significance based on conservation, recreational, ecological, historical, scientific, cultural, or esthetic qualities, living marine resources, and resource or human-use values. It also addresses the need for coordinated conservation and management efforts when existing authorities are insufficient. The National Marine Sanctuaries Act is amended to facilitate conservation and management efforts in designated areas of special national significance. Amendments include changes to sections regarding the Secretary's responsibilities and effective date of the Act. SEC. 206. WESTERN PACIFIC PROJECT GRANTS. Amendment authorizes $500,000 annually for Section 111(b)(1) of the Sustainable Fisheries Act.
